Identity.History: Although the earliest mentions of stone throwing machines reach back much earlier, the first Greek catapult (Lithobolos) was developed in the early 4th century B.C. during Dionysius of Syracuse's expedition against the Carthaginians. Other than many weapons at the time, the lithobolos was powered by a torsion mechanism. Torsion-based weapons can store and release energy more efficiently than tension-based weapons (like bows and crossbows). Compared to the oxybeles (Greek bolt shooter), the lithobolos was bigger, heavier, and more powerful and just had one single arm facing forward. One end of the arm was attached to the torsion mechanism. As the arm was rotated backwards to place the projectile on a cup or sling at the other end, a bundle of sinew, skein, or fiber was twisted. When the arm was released, the bundle unwound, launching the projectile at a 45-degree angle upward. The lithobolos could throw 150-pound stones hundreds of yards away. It was used to damage defensive structures such as walls or towers. Because catapults were so heavy and bulky, they were carried in pieces and assembled on the battlefield. The Seleucids adopted the fighting style of the Macedonians and used Greek (or Macedonian) siege engines, including the lithobolos.
